title: How to Make Lemon Pepper Wings

steps.headline: Heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Pour enough canola oil into a large, heavy-bottomed pot to fill it halfway. Preheat the oil over medium-high heat until it reaches a temperature of 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius). You could also use a deep-fryer if you have one. Otherwise, nearly any heavy-bottomed pot should work. Check the temperature of the oil with a cooking thermometer. It must remain between 350 and 375 degrees Fahrenheit (180 and 190 degrees Celsius) throughout the entire cooking process. Adjust the heat as needed to keep it within this range.

steps.headline: Combine the flour and black pepper.
steps.description: Place the flour and ground black pepper in a large resealable plastic bag. Seal the bag and shake to combine. If you don't have a large enough bag, combine the flour and pepper in a large bowl. Mix well to spread the pepper throughout the flour.

steps.headline: Dredge the chicken in the seasoned flour.
steps.description: Place the chicken in the bag of seasoned flour, seal the bag, and shake well until the pieces are completely yet lightly coated. It might be easiest to coat the chicken in batches. Work with one-quarter to one-third of the pieces at one time, and remove the previous batch before adding the next one.

steps.headline: Fry the chicken in the hot oil.
steps.description: Place the coated chicken in the preheated oil and fry until they are cooked through and begin to float. Fry the chicken wings in two or three batches to avoid over-crowding the pan. If you try to fry too many at once, the pieces may stick together and the temperature of the oil may drop too low. Note that each batch will usually take 8 to 10 minutes. The chicken wings should no longer be pink inside when finished, and the juices should run clear. If desired, you can also check for doneness with an instant-read meat thermometer. The thermometer should read 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius) once the chicken is ready.

steps.headline: Toss the cooked chicken into the lemon juice.
steps.description: Transfer each piece of finished chicken into a shallow bowl filled with lemon juice. Toss gently to coat the chicken. You do not need to drain the oil off the chicken before dunking it in lemon juice, but you should hold each piece above the oil for several seconds to allow some of the excess oil to drip off.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the pieces with lemon pepper.
steps.description: Take the wings out of the lemon juice and transfer them to a serving plate. Season well with lemon pepper. Coat all sides of each wing with lemon pepper seasoning. If you don't have lemon pepper seasoning, combine equal parts dried grated lemon zest and ground black pepper, then coat the chicken with that.

steps.headline: Serve immediately.
steps.description: Enjoy the lemon pepper wings while they're still hot for the best flavor.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Prepare a standard 15x10x1-inch (38x25x3-cm) baking sheet by lining it with aluminum foil. Spray the foil with nonstick cooking spray. Even if you use nonstick aluminum foil, you should still spray the foil with cooking spray to further reduce the risk of sticking.

steps.headline: Coat the chicken with cooking spray.
steps.description: Place the chicken on the baking sheet and evenly coat the top side of each piece with cooking spray. Arrange the pieces skin-side up during this step. Make sure that they remain in a single layer and do not overlap. The cooking spray should help the seasoning stick to the skin of the chicken. You could also brush the surface with a small amount of olive oil or canola oil to accomplish the same effect.

steps.headline: Sprinkle with lemon pepper.
steps.description: Generously and evenly sprinkle the lemon pepper seasoning over the chicken wings. Use roughly half of the total desired amount. If you do not have lemon pepper seasoning, make your own mixture by combining equal parts ground black pepper and dried lemon zest.

steps.headline: Flip and coat again.
steps.description: Use tongs to turn the wings over to the uncoated side. Spray this side with cooking spray and sprinkle it with the remaining lemon pepper seasoning. Note that the skin-side of the wings should now face down. Leave it that way for the time being.

steps.headline: Bake for 35 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the chicken until done, turning the wings once halfway through the the cooking process. Use tongs to flip the chicken pieces after approximately 15 minutes, then continue baking the chicken for another 20 minutes or until the skin turns brown and crispy. If some of the lemon pepper seasoning stuck to the foil, you can add more upon flipping the pieces. The finished wings should no longer be pink inside, and the juices should run clear. An instant-read meat thermometer should reach 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius) when inserted into the meat and away from the bone.

steps.headline: Serve immediately.
steps.description: Remove the finished lemon pepper wings from the oven. Garnish with parsley, if desired, and enjoy while still hot.

steps.headline: Combine the brine ingredients.
steps.description: Place the salt, sugar, and water in a large resealable plastic bag. Seal and shake to combine. Continue shaking up the brine until the salt and sugar completely dissolve. Mixing the brine in a resealable bag works best, but you can also prepare it in a large mixing bowl. Simply stir the ingredients together until the salt and sugar dissolve, then cover the bowl with plastic wrap while brining the chicken.

steps.headline: Brine the chicken wings for 1 hour.
steps.description: Place the chicken in the brine and seal the bag. Let it sit in your refrigerator for 45 to 60 minutes. Turn the bag after the first 30 minutes so that the brine evenly soaks into all sides of the chicken wings.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry the wings.
steps.description: After 60 minutes, remove the chicken from the brine. Rinse off the excess brine and dry each piece with clean paper towels. Discard the leftover brine after removing the chicken. You can grill the wings immediately after removing them or wait another hour. If you choose to wait, place the wings on a baking sheet lined with clean paper towels and return it to the refrigerator. Allow the chicken to dry and chill uncovered.

steps.headline: Preheat the grill for indirect heat.
steps.description: Lightly coat the grate of a gas or charcoal grill with oil, then preheat it for cooking with indirect heat. For a charcoal grill: pile the coals on either side of the grill and place a foil drip pan in between the two mounds. Keep the grill grate above the coals and the pan. For a gas grill: preheat the grill with all burners set on high heat, then turn the center burner off and adjust the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius). Place a drip pan in the center, keeping it beneath the grill grate.

steps.headline: Toss the wings in oil.
steps.description: Place the wings in a large mixing bowl and add the olive oil. Toss well to lightly and evenly coat the wings. If excess oil remains in the bowl after you coat the wings, drain it before proceeding to the next step.

steps.headline: Sprinkle with lemon pepper seasoning.
steps.description: Sprinkle in the lemon pepper seasoning. Toss the chicken wings to coat all sides. Add the seasoning 1 Tbsp (15 ml) at a time, tossing well after each addition. Continue until the chicken pieces are coated to suit your own personal tastes. If you don't have lemon pepper seasoning, you could prepare your own by combining equal parts dried lemon zest and ground black pepper.

steps.headline: Cook for 45 to 60 minutes.
steps.description: Place the chicken wings on center of the grill grate (the indirectly heated area). Grill, flipping as needed, until the skin is crispy and the chicken is done. You'll need to flip the wings with tongs every 15 minutes or so to evenly brown the skin. The finished chicken pieces should reach an internal temperature of 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius). The juices should also run clear, and the inside should no longer be pink.

steps.headline: Serve immediately.
steps.description: Remove the lemon pepper wings from the grill and transfer them to a serving platter. Enjoy the wings while they're still hot.

text: Method One: Fried Heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius). Pour enough canola oil into a large, heavy-bottomed pot to fill it halfway. Preheat the oil over medium-high heat until it reaches a temperature of 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius). You could also use a deep-fryer if you have one. Otherwise, nearly any heavy-bottomed pot should work. Check the temperature of the oil with a cooking thermometer. It must remain between 350 and 375 degrees Fahrenheit (180 and 190 degrees Celsius) throughout the entire cooking process. Adjust the heat as needed to keep it within this range. Combine the flour and black pepper. Place the flour and ground black pepper in a large resealable plastic bag. Seal the bag and shake to combine. If you don't have a large enough bag, combine the flour and pepper in a large bowl. Mix well to spread the pepper throughout the flour. Dredge the chicken in the seasoned flour. Place the chicken in the bag of seasoned flour, seal the bag, and shake well until the pieces are completely yet lightly coated. It might be easiest to coat the chicken in batches. Work with one-quarter to one-third of the pieces at one time, and remove the previous batch before adding the next one. Fry the chicken in the hot oil. Place the coated chicken in the preheated oil and fry until they are cooked through and begin to float. Fry the chicken wings in two or three batches to avoid over-crowding the pan. If you try to fry too many at once, the pieces may stick together and the temperature of the oil may drop too low. Note that each batch will usually take 8 to 10 minutes. The chicken wings should no longer be pink inside when finished, and the juices should run clear. If desired, you can also check for doneness with an instant-read meat thermometer. The thermometer should read 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius) once the chicken is ready. Toss the cooked chicken into the lemon juice. Transfer each piece of finished chicken into a shallow bowl filled with lemon juice. Toss gently to coat the chicken. You do not need to drain the oil off the chicken before dunking it in lemon juice, but you should hold each piece above the oil for several seconds to allow some of the excess oil to drip off. Sprinkle the pieces with lemon pepper. Take the wings out of the lemon juice and transfer them to a serving plate. Season well with lemon pepper. Coat all sides of each wing with lemon pepper seasoning. If you don't have lemon pepper seasoning, combine equal parts dried grated lemon zest and ground black pepper, then coat the chicken with that. Serve immediately. Enjoy the lemon pepper wings while they're still hot for the best flavor. Method Two: Baked Preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius). Prepare a standard 15x10x1-inch (38x25x3-cm) baking sheet by lining it with aluminum foil. Spray the foil with nonstick cooking spray. Even if you use nonstick aluminum foil, you should still spray the foil with cooking spray to further reduce the risk of sticking. Coat the chicken with cooking spray. Place the chicken on the baking sheet and evenly coat the top side of each piece with cooking spray. Arrange the pieces skin-side up during this step. Make sure that they remain in a single layer and do not overlap. The cooking spray should help the seasoning stick to the skin of the chicken. You could also brush the surface with a small amount of olive oil or canola oil to accomplish the same effect. Sprinkle with lemon pepper. Generously and evenly sprinkle the lemon pepper seasoning over the chicken wings. Use roughly half of the total desired amount. If you do not have lemon pepper seasoning, make your own mixture by combining equal parts ground black pepper and dried lemon zest. Flip and coat again. Use tongs to turn the wings over to the uncoated side. Spray this side with cooking spray and sprinkle it with the remaining lemon pepper seasoning. Note that the skin-side of the wings should now face down. Leave it that way for the time being. Bake for 35 minutes. Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the chicken until done, turning the wings once halfway through the the cooking process. Use tongs to flip the chicken pieces after approximately 15 minutes, then continue baking the chicken for another 20 minutes or until the skin turns brown and crispy. If some of the lemon pepper seasoning stuck to the foil, you can add more upon flipping the pieces. The finished wings should no longer be pink inside, and the juices should run clear. An instant-read meat thermometer should reach 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius) when inserted into the meat and away from the bone. Serve immediately. Remove the finished lemon pepper wings from the oven. Garnish with parsley, if desired, and enjoy while still hot. Method Three: Grilled Combine the brine ingredients. Place the salt, sugar, and water in a large resealable plastic bag. Seal and shake to combine. Continue shaking up the brine until the salt and sugar completely dissolve. Mixing the brine in a resealable bag works best, but you can also prepare it in a large mixing bowl. Simply stir the ingredients together until the salt and sugar dissolve, then cover the bowl with plastic wrap while brining the chicken. Brine the chicken wings for 1 hour. Place the chicken in the brine and seal the bag. Let it sit in your refrigerator for 45 to 60 minutes. Turn the bag after the first 30 minutes so that the brine evenly soaks into all sides of the chicken wings. Rinse and dry the wings. After 60 minutes, remove the chicken from the brine. Rinse off the excess brine and dry each piece with clean paper towels. Discard the leftover brine after removing the chicken. You can grill the wings immediately after removing them or wait another hour. If you choose to wait, place the wings on a baking sheet lined with clean paper towels and return it to the refrigerator. Allow the chicken to dry and chill uncovered. Preheat the grill for indirect heat. Lightly coat the grate of a gas or charcoal grill with oil, then preheat it for cooking with indirect heat. For a charcoal grill: pile the coals on either side of the grill and place a foil drip pan in between the two mounds. Keep the grill grate above the coals and the pan. For a gas grill: preheat the grill with all burners set on high heat, then turn the center burner off and adjust the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius). Place a drip pan in the center, keeping it beneath the grill grate. Toss the wings in oil. Place the wings in a large mixing bowl and add the olive oil. Toss well to lightly and evenly coat the wings. If excess oil remains in the bowl after you coat the wings, drain it before proceeding to the next step. Sprinkle with lemon pepper seasoning. Sprinkle in the lemon pepper seasoning. Toss the chicken wings to coat all sides. Add the seasoning 1 Tbsp (15 ml) at a time, tossing well after each addition. Continue until the chicken pieces are coated to suit your own personal tastes. If you don't have lemon pepper seasoning, you could prepare your own by combining equal parts dried lemon zest and ground black pepper. Cook for 45 to 60 minutes. Place the chicken wings on center of the grill grate (the indirectly heated area). Grill, flipping as needed, until the skin is crispy and the chicken is done. You'll need to flip the wings with tongs every 15 minutes or so to evenly brown the skin. The finished chicken pieces should reach an internal temperature of 165 degrees Fahrenheit (74 degrees Celsius). The juices should also run clear, and the inside should no longer be pink. Serve immediately. Remove the lemon pepper wings from the grill and transfer them to a serving platter. Enjoy the wings while they're still hot.
